title: Celestial Alignment: Observing Six Planets in the Night Sky
summary: This weekend offers a notable astronomical event as six planets align in the evening sky, forming what is known as a planetary parade. Visible shortly after sunset, this alignment includes Mercury, Venus, Saturn, and Jupiter, which can be seen with the naked eye, while Uranus and Neptune require binoculars or a telescope for observation. The best viewing time in the UK is on Sunday, and observers should seek locations with a clear western horizon to maximize visibility. Dr. Becky Smethurst, an astronomer, explains that this phenomenon occurs because all planets orbit the Sun in a flat plane, similar to a spinning pizza dough flattening out, leading them to appear aligned from Earth's perspective. Jupiter, shining brightly in Gemini, will be the easiest to spot, even in light-polluted areas. Although seeing six planets together is not an everyday occurrence, it is relatively common compared to rarer seven-planet parades. This event provides an educational opportunity for skywatchers to explore planetary motions and celestial patterns.

background_read: The solar system consists of eight planets orbiting the Sun in a flat plane due to the conservation of angular momentum during its formation. Planetary alignments, or parades, occur when multiple planets appear in the same region of the sky from Earth's perspective, influenced by their orbital positions. Observational astronomy involves using tools like telescopes to study celestial objects, with events like this providing hands-on learning. Light pollution from urban areas can reduce visibility, making dark sky locations ideal for stargazing. Understanding these phenomena helps appreciate the dynamics of our solar system and encourages scientific curiosity.
